newsitem.title: USA: Dynamics rejects WHX's increased bid.
newsitem.headline: Dynamics rejects WHX's increased bid.

text.p: Dynamics Corp. of America said Monday it has rejected WHX Corp.'s sweetened $45-per share offer for 17 percent of the company's stock, calling the $11 million bid "inadequate."
Dynamics, which makes electrical appliances and electronic devices, said its board had voted unanimously to reject the offer and recommend that shareholders do the same.
The Dynamics board also voted to "explore alternative transactions to maximize shareholder value," the company said.
WHX increased its bid to $45 a share after Dynamics rejected a $40-a-share offer made on March 31.
WHX officials were not available for comment.
Dynamics also said it has postponed its annual meeting to Aug. 1 from May 2, and has added two new board members, expanding the board to nine members.
The two new board members are John Thompson, a principal at the consulting firm IMCOR, and Ronald Steiner, president of International Electronic Research Corp.
WHX last week offered $45 a share for 649,000 Dynamics shares, or 17 percent of the total, and said it would eventually seek to buy all Dynamics shares at $45 each.

WHX said that if it succeeded in buying the additional 17 percent, it would name its own members to Dynamics's board and adopt special by-laws permitting owners of more than a 9.9 percent stake to call special company meetings.

WHX already owns a 2.9 percent stake in Dynamics. Another 17 percent would put its ownership just under Dynamics's anti-takeover provision, or "poison pill," which kicks in when one party acquires a 20 percent stake.
Dynamics' stock rose $1.25 to $44.75, while WHX was unchanged at $6.50 on the New York Stock Exchange in afternoon trading.
